headline: Chicago Police Release Possible Suspects in Jussie Smollett Attack
summary: Chicago Police said they released two possible suspects without charging them in an alleged attack reported last month by “Empire” television star Jussie Smollett.

headline: Gunman Kills Five Employees in Illinois Factory Shooting
summary: A man being terminated after 15 years at an Aurora, Ill., factory opened fire in his workplace Friday afternoon, killing five employees and shooting five officers before being killed by police.

headline: Senate Panel Probes 2015 Meetings Involving Russian Maria Butina and Fed, Treasury Officials
summary: Senators are seeking information about Obama-era meetings between Treasury and Federal Reserve officials and Maria Butina, the alleged Russian agent who pleaded guilty to conspiring to influence U.S. policy.

headline: Paul Manafort Could Get Two-Decade Prison Sentence
summary: Paul Manafort could face more than 19 years in prison for crimes including not paying taxes on $16 million in income, prosecutors said.

headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: Corrections & Amplifications for the edition of Feb. 16-17, 2019

headline: Payless to Close All U.S. Stores as It Prepares for Another Bankruptcy
summary: Retailer Payless ShoeSource plans to close all of its roughly 2,100 stores in the U.S. and Puerto Rico, in what is likely to be the largest ever retailer liquidation.

headline: $1,973 LEDs and the Green New Deal
summary: How many union workers does it take to screw in a light bulb?

headline: Presidents and Guardrails
summary: Obama’s abuses are no justification for Trump’s emergency order.

headline: Another Subsidy Letdown
summary: Boston lured GE with millions. The company is now paying it back.

headline: New Jersey Attorney General Sends Subpoena to Trump Inaugural Committee
summary: President Trump’s inaugural committee has received a civil subpoena from the New Jersey attorney general, whose Consumer Protection Division is conducting an investigation into the fund.

headline: Euro Falls Amid Talk of New ECB Bank Loans
summary: The euro fell against the U.S. dollar and other developed-market currencies after investors interpreted a European Central Bank official’s discussion of a lending program for banks as a sign of the region’s economic weakness.

headline: Passaic River Cleanup Lawsuit Against YPF Headed to Trial
summary: Argentina’s YPF S.A. lost a bid for a pretrial victory in a multibillion-dollar fight over the cost of cleaning up the contaminated Passaic River.

headline: Gas Shortages Give New York an Early Taste of the Green New Deal
summary: The state is dependent on imports even though it sits atop the abundant Marcellus Shale.

headline: NotableQuotable: Ocasio-Cortez’s Aide
summary: ‘He was in fact a registered lobbyist for the Marijuana Policy Project.’

headline: America Is Torn Between Trump’s Fibs and Progressives’ Fantasies
summary: The president is a master of little lies, but the left rejects the big truths that sustain politics and culture.

headline: Judge Rules Roger Stone Can’t Make Media Appearances Outside Courthouse
summary: Roger Stone won’t be able talk to the media outside the courthouse where he is expected to face trial, a federal judge ruled Friday, saying that she wanted to ensure she could find a jury not “tainted” by the publicity.

headline: Citigroup Gives CEO 4% Pay Raise to $24 Million
summary: Citigroup Chief Executive Michael Corbat received a compensation package valued at $24 million in 2018, a 4% increase from the prior year.

headline: Judge Rules Westmoreland Coal Can Cut Retiree Benefits, Union Contracts
summary: Westmoreland Coal has received permission to end retiree benefits and scrap its union contracts with workers at two of its mines after the company said it needed to make dramatic cuts to its labor costs to survive bankruptcy.

headline: Appeals Court Says Puerto Rico Board Was Illegally Appointed
summary: The board overseeing Puerto Rico’s public finances was illegally appointed, a U.S. appeals court said in a Friday ruling that casts uncertainty over the U.S. territory’s high-stakes financial restructuring.

headline: Toys ‘R’ Dust: Mattel’s Bizarre Warning
summary: Weak categories still are weak, and Mattel appears less healthy than it made out just a week ago. Management should have been candid about that when reporting earnings instead of letting investors get unjustly excited.

headline: Kaepernick Resolves Collusion Grievance With NFL
summary: Colin Kaepernick and Eric Reid, the NFL stars who led national-anthem protests and alleged that the league’s teams colluded to penalize them for their political views, have resolved grievances they filed against the league.

headline: Contradictory Data Confound Economists
summary: Economic data are usually noisy, but this week included an onslaught of negative and often contradictory signals that made even seasoned economists scratch their heads.

headline: Commander Says U.S. Has Flexibility to Keep Some Troops in Syria
summary: The top U.S. commander in the Middle East said he is moving forward with plans to pull forces out of Syria, but said the military has the flexibility to leave some troops there if President Trump decides to maintain a military presence.

headline: Industrial Stocks Are Leading the Market for the First Time in Years
summary: Industrial shares are on track to drive the stock market’s gains on a quarterly basis for the first time in more than five years, fueling anxiety about a rapid unwind should trade negotiations with China stall.

headline: Private-Equity Firm Great Hill Partners in Talks to Buy Gizmodo Media Group
summary: Great Hill Partners is in exclusive talks with Univision Communications to buy Gizmodo Media Group, a deal that would add a marquee digital brand to the private-equity firm’s portfolio.

headline: Secrets of Wealthy Women: How to Become an Angel Investor
summary: Gothan Gal blogger and angel investor Joanne Wilson says she enjoys mentoring founders of startups but warns that such investments are huge gambles. Listen to her interview with Veronica Dagher in this episode of the Secrets of Wealthy Women podcast.

headline: Photos of the Week: Feb. 9-15, 2019
summary: Iran marks its 40th anniversary, a Belgian castle is on the market, an uphill battle for fashion and more from The Wall Street Journal’s Photos of the Week: Feb. 9-15, 2019.

headline: U.S. Treasury Yields Tick Higher Amid Trade Hopes
summary: U.S. government bond yields edged higher but hovered in a narrow range as traders favored riskier assets amid signs of progress in U.S.-China trade talks.

headline: Oil Climbs as OPEC Supply Drops
summary: Oil prices neared a three-month high, building on robust weekly gains driven by signs of shrinking global supply.

headline: Apollo to Buy Majority Stake in Cox TV Stations
summary: Apollo Global Management has reached a deal with Cox Enterprises to buy a majority stake in its television stations and its Ohio radio and newspaper properties.

headline: Mexico Relocates Hundreds of Migrants From Border City
summary: Hundreds of Central American migrants encamped in Mexico’s border city of Piedras Negras, across from Eagle Pass, Texas, are being relocated to other cities after a group of migrants rioted earlier this week and attempted to leave an abandoned factory where they were being held.

headline: Russia Detains American Founder of Private-Equity Firm, Straining U.S. Ties Further
summary: Russian authorities detained the American founder of a private equity group on suspicion of fraud, an incident that could rattle potential foreign investors and add to already strained ties between the U.S. and Russia.

headline: 23 Winter Escapes for Sunseekers
summary: Even in the depths of winter, it’s ‘summer’ somewhere. Here, our favorite getaways.

headline: An American Icon That Almost Wasn’t
summary: Daniel Chester French’s famed statue in the Lincoln Memorial exists thanks to artistic perseverance, political determination, and a little luck.

headline: Ilhan Omar’s History of America
summary: The United States as Cold War villain.

headline: Former Massachusetts Gov. Weld Launches Long-Shot Primary Challenge to Trump
summary: William Weld, the former governor of Massachusetts, is forming a presidential exploratory committee to challenge President Trump in the primaries, calling the president “too unstable” to lead the country.

headline: Two Former Cognizant Executives Charged in Bribery Probe
summary: Two former executives of Cognizant Technology Solutions were charged by U.S. authorities with foreign bribery for allegedly approving illicit payments in India to build a corporate campus there.

headline: Supreme Court Agrees to Decide Census Citizenship Question
summary: The Supreme Court said that it would move quickly to decide whether the Trump administration can ask U.S. residents on the 2020 census whether they are citizens, a case infused with time pressures and immigration politics.

headline: GE to Scale Back Boston HQ, Return $87 Million of Incentives
summary: General Electric is scaling back its planned Boston headquarters, including selling the property and dropping plans to add hundreds of jobs.

headline: Canada’s Trudeau Looks to Contain Fallout from Justice Uproar
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau attempted to contain the fallout of a political firestorm over allegations of judicial interference, saying he told his former justice minister the decision of whether to prosecute a global engineering company on bribery-and-fraud charges was hers.

headline: The Economy Is Probably Fine, but ...
summary: The Federal Reserve reported January industrial-production figures, and they were weak. The economy’s soft patch keeps looking softer.

headline: Deere Says Trade Tensions Holding Down Sales
summary: Deere & Co. said farmers are delaying purchases of machinery as they wait for a resolution of trade standoffs between the U.S. and major foreign buyers of farm commodities such as China.

headline: Virginia’s Black Caucus Gains Strength Amid Political Turmoil
summary: In a state that went much of the 20th century without any African-American representation in the capitol, the Virginia Legislative Black Caucus has taken a lead in plotting a course through recent leadership scandals.

headline: When Investing on Auto-Pilot Isn’t Enough
summary: Recent events at Highland Global Allocation Fund are a reminder that eternal vigilance is the price of investing, Jason Zweig writes.

headline: Vatican Envoy to France Is Investigated for Sexual Assault Charge
summary: French authorities placed the Vatican’s envoy to France under investigation for allegedly sexually assaulting a local Paris official last month, the latest in a string of embarrassing episodes involving Holy See diplomats.

headline: Newell Warns That Sales Declines Will Continue
summary: Newell, which owns brands including Rubbermaid and Sharpie, forecast another year of sales declines even though one of its business segments returned to growth in its latest quarter.

headline: Uber Sales Growth Slows Further as IPO Nears
summary: Uber Technologies, as it steers toward a planned IPO later this year, reported its slowest sales growth since the company began disclosing detailed financials two years ago.

headline: South Dakota Sen. Rounds Calls for Evaluation of Indian Health Service
summary: Sen. Mike Rounds (R., S.D.) introduced legislation calling for a broad assessment of the Indian Health Service, following an investigation of the agency by The Wall Street Journal and PBS series Frontline.

headline: Wells Fargo Chief Is Expected to Appear Solo Before House Panel
summary: Wells Fargo is expected to be the first bank to face a grilling by House Democrats who took over the Financial Services Committee in the new Congress, with a March hearing focused on its scandals.

headline: The Stadium Reverse Curse
summary: None

headline: Illinois Governor to Sign Bill Raising Minimum Wage to $15 an Hour by 2025
summary: Business groups oppose labor-backed measure raising minimum from $8.25.

headline: EU’s Trade Surplus With U.S., a Bone of Contention for Trump, Hits Record
summary: The European Union reported a record trade surplus with the U.S. last year, a development that could weigh on slow-moving U.S.-EU trade talks and comes as the Trump administration prepares to deliberate hefty tariffs on European car imports.

headline: Amazon Invests in Electric-Car Maker Rivian
summary: Amazon.com has climbed aboard the electric-vehicle bandwagon, leading a $700 million investment round for car-making startup Rivian Automotive.

headline: The Good Death: On Leaving This World in a Satisfying Way
summary: But I worry that the desire to have a “good” death adds to a patient’s burden of health-associated guilt in this complex and unpredictable world.

headline: His Predecessors Set a Low Bar for President Trump’s Crisis Handling
summary: Peggy Noonan glosses over the crises of other presidents and homes in on how President Trump might poorly respond in such situations.

headline: Management Guru Jim Collins Is Probing New Problems
summary: After decades devoted to the mechanics of corporate success, Mr. Collins is turning his attention to K-12 education and the secrets of self-renewal.

headline: Scott Walker Was Productively Conservative to the End
summary: Wisconsin’s former Gov. Walker’s achievements include steady year-by-year reduction of the burden of government, record low unemployment, high educational results and a near-best rating in funding of public pensions.

headline: India’s Modi Warns Pakistan of Reprisal for Kashmir Attack
summary: Indian authorities said they would punish Pakistan for an attack that killed at least 40 Indian security personnel, putting India’s long-festering friction with its neighbor at the center of political debate just months ahead of national elections.

headline: Thoughts on Sears Long Decline and Edward Lampert’s Bankruptcy Bid
summary: Buy a solid, ongoing business with valuable assets. Load it with debt that pays you back. Invest nothing in the business. Strip out most of the assets that have any value.

headline: Coke and Pepsi Leave Different Aftertastes
summary: Results from Pepsi and Coca-Cola got different receptions but highlight similar strains facing U.S. consumer-goods companies.

headline: The Science of Better Meetings
summary: You can’t abolish office gatherings, but you can make them shorter, smaller and smarter with the help of recent research

headline: U.S. Consumer Sentiment Rises
summary: Consumers’ outlook for the U.S. economy rose in early February as American households absorbed the end of the government shutdown and the Federal Reserve’s decision to pause its rate increases.

headline: Tom Fatjo Discovered Gold Mine in Garbage
summary: Houston entrepreneur Tom Fatjo founded garbage-hauling giant Browning-Ferris Industries before vowing to create ‘the IBM of Fitness,’ a chain of health clubs in the 1980s that slipped into bankruptcy.

headline: Rosemary Mariner, Spurned by Airline Executive, Led Way for Female Pilots in U.S. Navy
summary: Rosemary Mariner, described by a friend as “a champion of people,” landed on aircraft carriers, rose to the rank of captain and became the first woman to command a military aviation squadron.

headline: Best-Selling Books, Week Ended Feb. 9
summary: Best-selling books, week ended Feb. 9, with data from NPD BookScan.

headline: Rival Logistics Operators Bid for Swiss Freight Major
summary: Global logistics operators in Denmark and Kuwait are vying for control of Swiss freight major Panalpina, potentially setting off a bidding war over consolidation in the world-wide market for industrial transport trade.

headline: WSJ. Magazine Contributors: March 2019
summary: Writer Hari Kunzru contributed to this issue of the magazine

headline: WSJ. Magazine Editor’s Letter: Ripeness Is All
summary: Editor in Chief Kristina O’Neill introduces the March 2019 issue of WSJ. Magazine

headline: The Secret to Searing Pork Chops Without Setting Off a Smoke Alarm
summary: Spoiler alert: It’s all about frequent flipping. Bonus: You’ll have this gorgeous meal of juicy chops plus garlicky beans and greens on the table in a mere 25 minutes.

headline: ‘Spearhead’ Review: Beyond the Front Lines
summary: In World War II, every American tank became a rolling town on tracks.

headline: Real-Estate Deals Targeted Again in Renewed Russia Sanctions Bill
summary: A bipartisan group of U.S. senators reintroduced sanctions legislation this week targeting Russia that also includes a provision tackling money laundering in all-cash purchases of real estate.

headline: ‘Lincoln’s Confidant’ Review: The Friend Who Listened
summary: Journalist Noah Brooks didn’t think much of Lincoln when they met in 1856. But the two men became friends when Brooks went to Washington six years later, and his conversations with Lincoln are essential to how we understand the era.

headline: Five Best: Laura Marcus on Memoirs of Childhood
summary: The author, most recently, of ‘Autobiography: A Very Short Introduction’ selects writers’ accounts of their early lives.

headline: Fiction: The Flavor of the American Century
summary: A fizzy, thrilling history of the rise and fall of an imagined soda-pop empire.

headline: ‘Becoming Lincoln’ Review: The Center That Held
summary: How did Lincoln respond to deep social division? As president he avoided insults or self-promotion. While pushing for justice, he tried to position himself as a pragmatist.

headline: ‘Landfall’ Review: How It Really Never Happened
summary: Thomas Mallon’s superbly written novel about the George W. Bush administration takes its characters more seriously than the media of the time took their real-life counterparts.

headline: ‘Goodbye to Tenth Street’ Review: A Final Sweeping
summary: A lively novel of the Abstract Expressionist art scene that is everything you’d expect from critic Irving Sandler, who seemingly befriended every painter, writer and dealer in 1950s New York.

headline: Children’s Books: Tales Well Worth Repeating
summary: A reissued classic and 10 old yarns cleverly ‘respun.’

headline: The Structure of Abstraction
summary: Born in Germany, Hans Hofmann found inspiration in American landscapes

headline: Mysteries: Still Prepared to Kill
summary: In Kate Quinn’s thriller a woman who killed Jewish refugees during World War II makes a new life in Boston—but is still prepared to kill.

headline: Factory Output Contracts Unexpectedly in January
summary: U.S. industrial output fell sharply in January, primarily driven by a large drop in vehicle production.

headline: Stocks to Watch: Nvidia, CBS, Deere, PepsiCo, Newell, FedEx
summary: Nvidia, CBS, Deere, PepsiCo, Caesars Entertainment, Applied Materials, Newell Brands, Oracle, FedEx, Redfin are among Friday’s stocks to watch.

headline: Download the WSJ Tax Guide E-Book
summary: Download ‘The New World of Taxes: 2019.’

headline: Regulators Block Fewer M&A Deals
summary: The number of deals blocked by regulators is falling, recent data show as, some merger partners show a willingness to compromise over issues such as gaining too much pricing power in certain markets.

headline: The Latest Chapter in Europe’s Electoral Challenges: Spain
summary: Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez called snap elections for late April, bringing the curtain down early on a short-lived government and pitching Spain into a vote that could showcase the rising strength of a new, hard-right party.

headline: Big Dividends Close Door on Battered Bank’s Desperate Decade
summary: Royal Bank of Scotland has escaped its desperate decade—the years in which the world’s largest bank by assets on the eve of the 2008 crisis was battered, bailed out and, for a long time, badly managed.

headline: Buy Low on LeBron James and the Lakers
summary: The Lakers are in jeopardy of missing the NBA playoffs. Here’s why they’re better than you think. (Hint: They still have a guy who’s pretty good at basketball.)

headline: What You Need to Know About the New Tax Law (Now That You’re Doing Your Taxes)
summary: The Wall Street Journal’s 2019 Tax Guide will help you sort through the confusion of doing your taxes for the first time under the new law.

headline: 529 Education Savings Accounts
summary: These plans can now be used to pay up to $10,000 of K-12 private-school tuition, but clarifications are needed in some states.

headline: The Retail Industry
summary: The tax cut could help an industry spending heavily to fight Amazon and adapt to shifting consumer habits.

headline: The Alternative Minimum Tax
summary: After vowing to kill the AMT, Republicans kept this unpopular levy, but they revised it to affect far fewer people.

headline: Depreciation for Business Equipment
summary: Tax law allows companies to immediately write off 100% of equipment purchases, an extraordinary—albeit temporary—perk.

headline: Estate and Gift Taxes
summary: Lawmakers didn’t repeal the estate tax, but they doubled the exemption, reducing the number of liable estates.

headline: Child and Dependent Tax Credit
summary: The child credit doubled and became available to more families, a move that more than offset the repeal of the personal exemption in many cases.

headline: The Housing Market
summary: By shrinking the tax benefits of homeownership, the tax law is starting to have a big impact on the housing market.

headline: Charitable-Donation Tax Deduction
summary: The overhaul didn’t make major changes to these deductions, but the near-doubling of the standard deduction means far fewer filers will choose to itemize.

headline: Taxes on Investment Income
summary: The overhaul made few changes to investment-income taxes, preserving the favorable rates for capital gains and dividends.

headline: The Banking Industry
summary: For banks, after some initial pain, the tax overhaul has been a multibillion-dollar windfall.

headline: Alimony
summary: Future alimony payments are expected to shrink as a result of the tax overhaul.

headline: Withholding and Estimated Tax Payments
summary: Employees should refigure paycheck withholding or risk unwelcome surprises.

headline: Mortgage-Interest Deduction
summary: The near-doubling of the standard deduction and caps on eligible mortgages mean fewer will take popular write-off.

headline: Home-Seller’s Exemption
summary: Nothing changed with this tax exemption, despite an initial effort by House Republicans to reduce the benefit.

headline: Medical-Expenses Deduction
summary: After considering ending it, lawmakers retained this write-off and made it slightly more generous.

headline: The Drug Industry
summary: The tax overhaul has given pharmaceutical companies that generate hefty  sales outside the U.S. the chance to bring their accumulated overseas cash home at a preferential rate.

headline: New Tax Rates and Brackets
summary: Tax overhaul changed rates and income brackets, but whether people owe more or less will often depend on other provisions.

headline: The Tech Industry
summary: Tech companies paid low effective tax rates under the old system by booking profits in low-tax foreign jurisdictions. The new law seeks to curtail the practice.

headline: Retiree Tax Issues
summary: The overhaul didn’t change the taxation of Social Security benefits or retirement-plan distributions, but the large increase in the standard deduction will benefit many retirees.

headline: The Telecom Industry
summary: Telecom carriers are benefiting from the lower tax rate and a 100% write-off on capital investments as they gear up for next-generation 5G networks.

headline: Other Education Benefits
summary: The House had planned a major shake-up—but in the end, Congress passed very few changes.

headline: Retirement Savings
summary: Tax law changes time frame of 401(k) loan repayments and ends savers’ ability to ‘undo’ Roth IRA conversions.

headline: The Individual Mandate
summary: The Obamacare requirement to have health insurance or pay a penalty is gone for 2019.

headline: The Political Implications of the Tax Overhaul
summary: The tax law was the GOP’s biggest achievement, but it remained unpopular as Republicans tried to use it to win elections.

headline: Interest Payments on Business Debt
summary: The tax overhaul put a cap on the amount of interest cost that most companies can deduct.

headline: Other Tax Deductions
summary: Many write-offs have been curtailed, including those for unreimbursed employee travel expenses.

headline: Standard-Deduction Expansion and Personal Exemption
summary: The expansion of the standard deduction and repeal of the personal exemption affect millions of Americans.

headline: The ‘Kiddie Tax’
summary: The overhaul greatly simplified a special levy on a child’s ‘unearned’ income, but the shift in rates is unfavorable for some.

headline: Deduction for Pass-Through Income
summary: Owners of pass-through businesses get a break—but figuring out who is eligible could be challenging.

headline: State and Local Tax Deduction
summary: The overhaul capped the deduction for state and local taxes at $10,000 per return

headline: BP: Renewables and Natural Gas to Dominate Energy Growth
summary: The vast majority of global energy supply growth is expected to come from renewables and natural gas over the next two decades, but steep investment in oil exploration and production will be needed to meet crude demand in 2040, according to BP.

headline: A Look at African-American History, Through the Numbers
summary: Four hundred years ago, the first Africans arrived in what is now the U.S. In recognition of that anniversary and Black History Month, here are a few numbers that help describe their experience and that of their descendants.

headline: New Consumer CEOs Are Getting Tougher, Shorter Jobs
summary: Running a multibillion-dollar consumer company is a more bruising job than it used to be. The new bosses may struggle to last as long as the retiring ones.

headline: China’s Didi to Lay Off 2,000 Workers
summary: Chinese ride-hailing giant Didi Chuxing Technology plans to lay off about 2,000 employees, or 15% of its workforce, as the once fast-growing company grapples with China’s economic slowdown.

headline: Hulu Ad Campaign Spells Out That Its Influencers Get Paid
summary: Streaming service Hulu is adding an element of ’authenticity’ to its marketing with a campaign where endorsers reveal they are getting paid to be on air.

headline: ICE Wants to Bring First ‘Speed Bump’ to Futures Markets
summary: A proposal to blunt the advantages of ultrafast traders in one corner of the futures market is threatening to shake up the high-frequency trading world.

headline: ‘Fortnite’ Effect: The Game Never Ends
summary: Big videogame makers Electronic Arts, Activision Blizzard and Take-Two Interactive are learning that their blockbuster titles need staying power to capitalize on the games-as-a-service trend.

headline: Purchases With Plastic Get Costlier for Merchants—and Consumers
summary: Visa and Mastercard are increasing a range of fees that U.S. merchants will pay to process transactions starting in April, a move likely to inflame already fractious relations between many businesses and card networks.

headline: Fake News Rattles Nigerian Election Campaign
summary: As fake news proliferates in Africa, Nigeria’s government has warned that misinformation is threatening the credibility of Saturday’s election.

headline: Myanmar Court Sentences Two Men to Death for Killing of Suu Kyi Aide
summary: Two years after an adviser to Myanmar’s civilian leader, Aung San Suu Kyi, was assassinated outside the country’s main international airport, a court handed down death sentences for two men, including the gunman who fired the fatal bullet.

headline: How to Depress Chinese Consumers Without Really Trying
summary: It’s now widely recognized that China’s campaign to curtail shadow banking has damaged private enterprises. Less widely recognized is the burden it places on households—and consumers of products like the iPhone.

headline: Drone Scare Grounds Flights at Dubai Airport
summary: Dubai International Airport, the world’s busiest international hub, briefly suspended flights because of the suspected presence of a drone, the latest in a string of global airports to have to ground flights.

headline: China’s Muted Inflation Likely to Spur Policy Easing
summary: Inflation moderated across the board in China last month in another sign of lethargic domestic demand—one that economists said gives the central bank more room to stimulate economic growth.

headline: Philippine Towns Blocked From Joining Muslim Self-Rule Region
summary: Six southern Philippine towns that voted to join a new self-governing Muslim region have had their decision effectively vetoed—a first challenge to a peace deal supporters hope will stem Islamic extremism.

headline: What’s News: World-Wide
summary: What’s News: World-Wide

headline: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: What’s News: Business & Finance
summary: What’s News: Business & Finance

headline: Nigeria Braces for Climax of Rancorous Presidential Showdown
summary: The winner of Nigeria’s rancorous presidential contest—postponed to Feb. 23—will face sluggish economic growth, entrenched corruption and a dizzying array of security threats.

headline: The Tech Whiz Behind Vine and HQ Trivia Made Millions in His 20s. He Was Dead by 34
summary: Self-taught coder Colin Kroll shot to startup fame, allowing him to live life in a fast lane. Friends saw him as a gentle, endearingly awkward soul, but he also fought with colleagues, attracted negative press for his behavior at work and struggled with drugs and alcohol.

headline: Trump Declares Emergency Over Wall, Inviting Likely Court Fight
summary: President Trump declared a national emergency over border security, bypassing Congress to divert money from elsewhere in the government to pay for additional barriers along the southern border, a move likely to ignite immediate court challenges.

headline: Why Amazon’s New York U-Turn Is Good for America’s Tech Economy
summary: Amazon.com’s abandoned plans for a New York City headquarters may have prompted mixed reactions in the Big Apple, but for the rest of the country, it’s good news.

headline: U.S. Puts Sanctions on More Venezuelan Officials
summary: The U.S. sanctioned the head of Venezuela’s state-owned oil giant and five top intelligence and security officials and the Trump administration said it planned to deliver 200 tons of humanitarian aid to a border city in Colombia, intensifying its effort to ratchet up pressure on President Nicolás Maduro.

headline: Amazon Project Foundered on Labor Organizing, Debate Over Subsidies
summary: Amazon scuttled its New York City project after talks to resolve the matter of labor organizing and to ease political opposition to subsidies failed to allay the company’s concerns.

headline: Funding and Location of Wall Likely to Spark Conflicts
summary: President Trump’s proposal to move billions of dollarsfrom military spending and drug interdiction to fund the construction of 234 miles of barriers sets up two new conflicts: one over where the money is coming from, and one over where it might go.

headline: The Making of a DNA Detective
summary: CeCe Moore, an amateur genealogist turned professional, helps police crack decades-old cases.

headline: PepsiCo CEO Says No Plans to Break Up
summary: Ramon Laguarta said he has no plans to break up the snacks and drinks giant, nor divest the company’s bottling operations, after completing a four-month review of the global business.

headline: Investor Steve Jurvetson Works to Move On With New Fund
summary: Venture capitalist Steve Jurvetson is back on the investment scene with a new fund, more than a year after he was hit with allegations that he mistreated women and left the firm he co-founded.

headline: Ethics Office Notes Show ‘Evolving Stories’ on Trump’s Reimbursement of Cohen, House Oversight Committee Says
summary: The House Oversight Committee said it had received new documents from the Office of Government Ethics that showed President Trump’s lawyers gave the agency “evolving stories” about whether the president had reimbursed his former lawyer, Michael Cohen, for hush-money payments made during the 2016 campaign.

headline: Transcript: WSJ Interview With San Francisco Fed President Mary Daly
summary: San Francisco Fed leader Mary Daly discusses her outlook for interest rates and the economy, the winding down of the Fed’s bond portfolio, and reasons why a tight labor market hasn’t fueled stronger wage growth and higher inflation.

headline: Nasdaq Exits Bear Market as Stocks Rally
summary: The new year rally in technology stocks lifted the Nasdaq Composite to its eighth consecutive weekly rise, and the index exited from the bear market it entered in late 2018.

headline: Big Three Stock Exchanges Sue SEC Over Trading-Fee Plan
summary: In an unprecedented legal confrontation, the three biggest U.S. stock-exchange groups are taking on their own regulator to block an initiative that seeks to limit the fees they can charge for trading.

headline: Amazon’s Pivot Raises Scrutiny of Incentive Deals
summary: The collapse of Amazon’s plan to build a second headquarters in New York City has the potential to damp some states’ willingness to offer tax breaks.
